captions.text: Hey Vsauce I'm Jake and get ready to nAPP...All...zzzZZzzzZZzzz

What a beautiful day to OBLITERATE ZOMBIES.
In Dead Ahead you have to hop on your scooter,

outrun the undead that are chasing after you
and blow through the ones that stand in your

way. The more zombies you destroy and the
farther you go , the more coins you get to

use towards upgrading your vehicle, armory
or unlocking extra tracks. There are also

power-ups that give you unlimited ammo, quad
damage or a nitro boost. Any game where you

can drive what looks like the motorcycle from
Akira is ok with me. But instead of breaking
skulls, break blocks in
Mosaique. At first glance it looks like a pretty version

of brick breaker, but it is actually much
more complicated. If you only remove one block

with a shot, your power bar goes down. You
have to swap out blocks in order to create

a row of identically colored ones. The bigger
the combo, the more full your bar becomes.
You can move your piece across all 4 sides of the area and there

is no time limit so you can really plan out
all your decisions. But instead of thinking,
lets just
Knife that Guy.

You dash around the dance floor on the
hunt for said guy with a red arrow over his

head. Once you find him, take 'im out, but
avoid murdering people who aren't marked because

you are a responsible and socially conscious
maniac. The more you massacre, the faster

the game becomes and you get certain power-ups
depending on what color dance tile you do

the deed. Or maybe homicidal tendencies aren't
your

Flava, a clean and well designed app meant
for collecting your experiences. Every moment

you capture starts to form a timeline of your
life. You can make a note about a movie you

watched, a book you read, place you went,
and more. The events are organized by tags

and types making it incredibly easy to revisit
some precious memories. It's almost as easy
as playing

Musyc, a really cool and interactive music
creator where you make Rube Goldberg-esque

contraptions in order to produce awesome tracks.
Each shape has a different sound and you can

adjust each individual one's size, pitch,
delay and more. The shapes interact with the

environment as well, bouncing off walls you
create and other shapes. The background acts

as a scale as well so when an object moves
across the screen, it plays a different key.

This app is insanely fun and can really do
whatever you imagine, creating awesome things
like this...

Since music is math try Quento. Quento is
a mathematical puzzle game where you swipe

your finger across the board to create the
proper equation needed to solve the problem.

For some rounds you only have to combine two
numbers but it quickly jumps up to 3, adding

to the challenge. Even though there is no
time limit, it is really fun to try and see

how fast you can figure out the answer even
if it takes a Little Luca...

In Little Luca the stars in the sky have disappeared
and you are tasked with collecting them. You

have to use the terrain to bounce your ball
and collect all the stars to get them into

the black hole. There are different obstacles
like wind or whales that you'll need to take

advantage of in order to achieve your goal.
The game has a great visual style and sound

track but instead of bouncing your balls,
toss em at some cans.

Can Knockdown 3, is the Return of the King
of the Can trilogy. The graphics are amazingly
detailed and the can physics are pretty incredible.
There are

There are cans that explode, ones that give you an extra
ball, and the level set-ups are just plain

fun. Oh, and there is also a bullet time mode
so you can see that sweet can carnage. Then
put your balls down and get lost with

Hiversaires, a wordless point and click adventure
game. You have to navigate through an alien

labyrinth without knowing why you're there
or where exactly you are. Since all the symbols

you encounter are in an alien language, it
adds to this feeling of desolation and solitude.

You might not be able to decipher an alien
language but you can learn a foreign one in
this episode's app of the week...

Duolingo. Duolingo has been out for web and
iOS for awhile but is now available for Android

and it is an amazing app. You can learn French,
Spanish, German, Portuguese, Italian and English

completely for free. It turns learning a language
into a game as you lose hearts for errors,

level-up when you succeed and you can compete
against friends. One of the coolest parts

is that, as you progress and start completing
larger language translations, you are actually

helping translate the internet. If you are
trying to learn German like myself, and you

translate a German sentence into English,
you are actually helping translate some piece

of text on the web into a different language.
It is incredibly cool. And also I suck at
German.

Links to all the apps can be found in the
description below.
I'm Jake and as always, thanks for watching.
BONUS APPS!

Run in Crowd is a fun multiplayer game that
has you running endlessly against other players.

You have to avoid obstacles and giant holes
in the ground in order to reign supreme against

your competition. But let's go a on a trip,
a MindTrip.

MindTrip is a brain melting illusion app by
Vsaucer Husam Wadi. It includes 6 different

epilepsy inducing warps which, after staring
at them for 30 seconds, will make the world

distort around you. Or you could just not
see anything with

Blindscape. Blindscape is an adventure game
that you can't see. It is completely audio

based, and is a really interesting experience.
And I'm going to stop talking about it because
this gameplay footage isn't very exciting.

title: Throw Your Balls! -- App All Knight #14
